Detailed Description

Subclasses implement different backends
(GnuplotBackend for Gnuplot, for instance).

This base class saves info about plotting to instances of class Figure,
Line, and PlotItem.

List of "Matlab-like" interface functions (for the user):
...
List of internal helper functions (for subclasses):
...

def graphics.common.BaseClass.axes (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Create axes in arbitrary positions.

Calling axes() returns a default axis (Axis()).
Calling axes(ax) sets axes in the Axis instance ax as the current axis.
Calling axes(viewport=RECT) returns a axis at the position given in RECT.

Definition at line 1664 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.subplot (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Create axes in tiled positions.

Calling

    subplot(m,n,p)

breaks the Figure window into an m-by-n matrix of small axes,
selects the p-th axes for for the current plot, and returns the
axis handle.

Definition at line 1709 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.openfig (   self,
  filename = 'figspickle.txt' 
) 

Load figures saved in a file (with the given filename).
The format of this file is currently standard Python pickle format.
All figures in a previous session were dumped to the file, and
all these figures are by this method reloaded and added to the
current set of figures.

Definition at line 1730 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.savefig (   self,
  filename = 'figspickle.txt' 
) 

Save all current figures to a file (with the given filename).
The file has standard Python pickle format (dict of Figure instances).

Later, the figures can be reloaded by the openfig method.

Save a hardcopy of the current figure to file (with the given
filename).
The format of the file (image type) is determined from the
filename extension. If the format is not supported, PostScript
output will be used.

Definition at line 1828 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.axis (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Choose the axis limits.

Different arguments are allowed:

- axis([xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax[, zmin, zmax]])
  sets the scaling for the x-, y- and z-axes in the current plot.

- axis(xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax[, zmin, zmax])
  same as above.

- axis(mode)
  sets axis scaling to 'mode', where 'mode' can be 

     'auto'   - autoscaling is used
     'manual' - freeze the scaling at the current limits
     'tight'  - sets the axis limits to the range of the data
     'fill'   - 

- axis(method)
  sets the appearance of the current axis as specified by method.
  %s

- axis('on') or axis('off')
  turn axis on or off

Definition at line 1988 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.plot (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Draw line and scatter plots. 
 
    - plot(y)
      plots values in 'y' on y-axis (same as plot(range(len(y)),y) )  
 
    - plot(x, y)
      plots 'y' against 'x', i.e. if 'x' and 'y' are vectors of
      length n, then this will plot all the points (x[i], y[i])
      for 0<=i<n. 
 
    - plot(y, fmt)
      plots values in 'y' on y-axis formated like fmt (see below).
 
    - plot(x1,y1,fmt1, x2,y2,fmt2, ...)
      same as hold(1) followed by multiple plot(x,y,fmt).
 
    - plot(x1,y1,x2,y2,...)
      like above, but automatically chooses different colours.

    - plot(y1,...,x=x)
      uses 'x' as the x values for all the supplied curves.
      x='auto' has the same effect as x=range(len(y1)).
 
    - plot(...,log='x'), plot(...,log='xy') etc.
      draw logarithmic axes.

    - plot(...)
      returns a list a of all Line objects created.
    
 
the following format specifiers exist:
 
    y     yellow        .     point              -     solid
    m     magenta       o     circle             :     dotted
    c     cyan          x     x-mark             -.    dashdot 
    r     red           +     plus               --    dashed   
    g     green         *     star
    b     blue          s     square
    w     white         d     diamond
    k     black         v     triangle (down)
                ^     triangle (up)
                <     triangle (left)
                >     triangle (right)
                p     pentagram
                h     hexagram
 
Examples:

draws a line
>>> plot([1,2,3])
 
draws 3 red 'x'
>>> plot([1,2,3], 'rx')
 
Note: loglog, semilogy, semilogx are like plot(...,log='xy'),
plot(...,log='y') and plot(...,log='x').

Definition at line 2003 of file common.py.

  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Log-log scale plot.

- loglog(...) is the same as plot(...) except that a logarithmic
  scale is used for both the x- and y-axis.

Definition at line 2199 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.plot3 (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Draw lines and points in 3D space.
 
    - plot3(x, y, z)
      plots 'z' against 'x' and 'y', i.e. if 'x', 'y', and 'z' are
      vectors of length n, then this will plot all the points
      (x[i], y[i], z[i]) for 0<=i<n. 
  
    - plot3(z)
      plots values in 'z' on x and y-axis
      (same as plot3(range(len(z)), range(len(z)), z))

    - plot3(z, fmt)
      plots values in 'z' on z-axis formated like fmt (see plot).
 
    - plot3(x1,y1,z1,fmt1, x2,y2,z2,fmt2, ...)
      same as hold(1) followed by multiple plot3(x,y,z,fmt).
 
    - plot3(x1,y1,z1,x2,y2,z2,...)
      like above, but automatically chooses different colours.

    - plot3(z1,z2,...,x=x,y=y)
      uses 'x' as the x values and 'y' as the y values for all the
      supplied curves. x='auto' and y='auto' has the same effect as
      x=range(len(z1)) and y=range(len(z1)) respectively.
 
    - plot3(...)
      returns a list a of all created Line objects.

Definition at line 2383 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.quiver (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Quiver plot.

- quiver(X, Y, U, V)
  plots velocity vectors as arrows with components (u,v) at the
  points (x,y). The matrices X,Y,U,V must all be the same size and
  contain corresponding position and velocity components (X and Y
  can also be vectors to specify a uniform grid). 

- quiver(U, V)
  plots velocity vectors at equally spaced points in the x-y plane.
  (same as quiver(range(m),range(n),U,V) )

- quiver(..., 'filled')
  draw filled arrows

- quiver(..., LineSpec)
  sets the line specification as given in LineSpec. 

Examples:

>>> xx, yy = meshgrid(seq(-2,2,.2))
>>> zz = peaks(xx, yy)
>>> contour(xx, yy, zz, 10, hold='on')
>>> uu, vv = gradient(zz, .2)
>>> quiver(xx, yy, uu, vv)

Definition at line 2387 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.contour (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Draw a 2D contour plot.
 
- contour(X, Y, Z[, n])
  draw a contour plot were the values in the matrix 'Z' are treated
  as heights above a plane.

- contour(Z[, n])
  same as contour(range(n), range(m), Z[, n]) were m,n = shape(Z).

- contour(Z[, v])
  draw contours at levels specifyed in vector 'v'.

- contour(..., LineSpec)
  sets the line specification as given in LineSpec.

- contours(ax,...)
  use axis
  
- contour(...,clabels='on')
  same as contour(...) followed by clabel('on')

) 

Streamlines from 2D or 3D data.

- streamline(X,Y,Z,U,V,W,STARTX,STARTY,STARTZ)
- streamline(U,V,W,STARTX,STARTY,STARTZ)
  assumes X,Y,Z = meshgrid(seq(n-1), seq(m-1), seq(p-1))
  where m, n, p = shape(U)
##- streamline(XYZ))
- streamline(X,Y,U,V,STARTX,STARTY)
- streamline(U,V,STARTX,STARTY)
  assumes X,Y = meshgrid(seq(n-1), seq(m-1))
  where m, n = shape(U)
- streamline(XY)
- streamline(ax,...)
- streamline(...,options)
  where options can be [stepsize]
- h = streamline(...)

Examples:

Definition at line 2573 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.mesh (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Draw a 3D mesh surface.

- mesh(X, Y, Z[, C])
  plots the colored parametric mesh defined in the four matrix
  arguments. The color scaling is determined by the range of C. Uses
  C = Z if C is not given, so color is proportional to mesh height.
    
- mesh(Z[, C])
  same as mesh(range(n), range(m), Z[, C]) where m,n = shape(Z).
    
- mesh(x, y, Z[, C])
  the two vector arguments must have len(x) == n and len(y) == m,
  where m,n = shape(Z)

- mesh(ax, ...)
  plots into the Axis instance given in ax instead of the current axis.

Example:

>>> x = seq(-2,2,.2)
>>> xx, yy = meshgrid(x)
>>> zz = exp(-xx**2)*exp(-yy**2)
>>> mesh(xx, yy, zz)

Definition at line 2590 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.meshc (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Same as mesh(), but a contour plot is drawn beneath the mesh.

Examples:

Draw a mesh with contour lines:
>>> x = seq(-2,2,.2)
>>> xx, yy = meshgrid(x)
>>> zz = peaks(xx, yy)
>>> meshc(xx, yy, zz) 

Draw a mesh with 20 contour lines:
>>> meshc(xx, yy, zz, clevels=20)

Draw a mesh with contour lines at height -0.2, -0.5, 0.2, 0.5:
>>> meshc(xx, yy, zz, cvector=[-0.2,-0.5,0.2,0.5])

Draw a mesh with contours and label the contours:
>>> meshc(xx, yy, zz, clabels='on')

arguments.

>>> zz = xx**2 + yy**2
>>> surf(xx, yy, zz)

def graphics.common.BaseClass.quiver3 (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Draw velocity vectors in 3D.

- quiver3(X, Y, Z, U, V, W)
- quiver3(Z,U,V,W)
  assumes X, Y = meshgrid(seq(n-1), seq(m-1)) where m,n = shape(Z)
- quiver3(Z, U, V, W, s) or quiver3(X, Y, Z, U, V, W, s)
  scales the vectors by the scale factor given in s.
- quiver3(..., 'filled')
  fills the arrows
- quiver3(..., LineSpec)
  sets the specification on the arrows as given in LineSpec.
- quiver3(ax, ...)
  draws the vectors in the Axis instance given in ax instead of
  the current axis.
- h = quiver3(...)

Definition at line 2704 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.slice_ (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Volumetric slice plot.

- slice_(X,Y,Z,V,Sx,Sy,Sz)

- slice_(X,Y,Z,V,XI,YI,ZI)

- slice_(V,Sx,Sy,Sz) or slice_(V,XI,YI,ZI)
  same as slice_(seq(n), seq(m), seq(p)) where m,n,p = shape(V)

- slice_(...,'method')
  'method' can be 'linear' (default), 'cubic', or 'nearest'.

- slice(ax, ...)
  uses Axis instance in ax instead of the current axes.

- h = slice(...)

Examples:

>>> xx, yy, zz = meshgrid(seq(-2,2,.2), seq(-2,2,.25), seq(-2,2,.16))
>>> vv = x*exp(-xx**2-yy**2-zz**2)
>>> slice_(xx, yy, zz, vv, [-1.2,.8,2], 2, [-2,-.2])

Definition at line 2712 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.contourslice (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Contours in slice planes.

- contourslice(X,Y,Z,V,SX,SY,SZ)
  draws contour in axis aligned x,y,z planes at the points in the
  arrays SX, SY, and SZ.
  
- contourslice(X,Y,Z,V,XI,YI,ZI)
  draws contours through the volume V along the surface given in
  the arrays XI, YI, and ZI.
  
- contourslice(V,SX,SY,SZ) or contourslice(V,XI,YI,ZI)
  assumes X,Y,Z = meshgrid(seq(n-1), seq(m-1), seq(p-1))
  where m,n,p = shape(V).
  
- contourslice(..., n)
  draws n contours per plane.
  
- contourslice(..., cvals)
  draws len(cvals) contours per plane at levels given in cvals.
  
- contourslice(ax,...)
  draws into the Axis instance given in ax instead of the current
  axes.
  
- h = contourslice(...)
  returns con

Example:
xx, yy, zz = meshgrid(seq(-2,2,.2), seq(-2,2,.25), seq(-2,2,.16))
vv = xx*exp(-xx**2-yy**2-zz**2); # Create volume data
contourslice(xx, yy, zz, vv, [-.7,.7], [], [0], view=3)

Definition at line 2818 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.streamslice (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Streamlines in slice planes.

Example:
xx,yy = meshgrid(seq(-3,3,.2))
zz = peaks(xx,yy)
surf(xx,yy,zz)
shading('interp')
hold('on')
ch = contour3(xx,yy,zz,20);  ch.set(color='b')
uu,vv = gradient(zz)
h = streamslice(xx,yy,-uu,-vv); 
h.set(color='k')
for i in iseq(1,length(h); 
    zi = interp2(z,get(h(i),'xdata'),get(h(i),'ydata'));
    set(h(i),'zdata',zi);
end
view(30,50); axis tight

  where m,n,p = shape(V).

- isosurface(..., colors)

def graphics.common.BaseClass.camlookat (   self,
  args 
) 

Move camera and target to view specified objects.

- camlookat(h)
  views the object in h, where h is a PlotProperties instance.

- camlookat(ax)
  views objects in the Axis instance ax.

- camlookat()
  views objects in the current axes.

Definition at line 3142 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.camlight (   self,
  args,
  kwargs 
) 

Create or set position of a light.

- camlight('headlight')
  creates a light in the current axes at the camera position.

- camlight('right')
  creates a light right and up from the camera in the current axes.

- camlight('left')
  creates a light left and up from the camera.

- camlight()
  same as camlight('right')

- camlight(az, el)
  creates a light at az, el from the camera.

- camlight(..., style)
  style can be either 'local' (default), or 'inifinite'.

- camlight(h, ...)
  places Light instance h at the specified position.

- h = camlight(...)
  returns light instance.

  kwargs 
) 

Add a Light to the current axes.

- light()
  adds a light with default values for all light properties.

- light(param1=value1,param1=value2,...)
  adds a light with properties as given in the keyword arguments.

- h = light(...)
  returns Light instance that was created.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.colormap (   self,
  args 
) 

Specify colormap of the current figure.

- colormap(map)
  sets the colormap in 'map' as the current colormap.

- colormap('default')
  sets the colormap to the default colormap (jet).

- colormap()
  returns the current colormap.

- colormap(ax,...)
  sets the colormap in the axis 'ax' instead of the current axis.

Definition at line 3220 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.caxis (   self,
  args 
) 

Pseudocolor axis scaling.

- caxis([cmin, cmax]) or caxis(cmin, cmax)
  sets the pseudocolor axis scaling to range from 'cmin' to 'cmax'.

- caxis('manual')
  fixes axis scaling at the current range.
    
- caxis('auto')
  sets axis scaling back to autoranging.

- caxis()
  returns the current axis scaling.

- caxis(ax,...)
  uses the Axis instance in ax instead of the current axes.

Definition at line 3253 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.colorbar (   self,
  args 
) 

Display color bar (color scale) and return the color bar.

- colorbar()
  appends a colorbar to the current axes.

- colorbar('off')
  removes the colorbar from the current axes.

- colorbar(location)
  appends a colorbar to the current axes at location specified
  by 'location'. 'location' may be any of the following strings:

      'North'              inside plot box near top
      'South'              inside bottom
      'East'               inside right
      'West'               inside left
      'NorthOutside'       outside plot box near top
      'SouthOutside'       outside bottom
      'EastOutside'        outside right
      'WestOutside'        outside left

- colorbar(ax,...)
  appends a colorbar to the Axis instance specified by ax' instead
  of the current axis.

- h = colorbar(...)
  returns a Colorbar instance.

Definition at line 3293 of file common.py.

def graphics.common.BaseClass.shading (   self,
  args 
) 

Control the color shading of surfaces.

- shading(mode)
  sets the shading of the current graph to the shading mode specified
  by 'mode'. Valid modes are 'flat', 'interp' (interpolated) and
  'faceted'.

- shading(ax,...)
  uses axes 'ax' instead of the current axes.
